item.title: Decoded: GNU Coreutils (2018) (maizure.org)
item.description: Decoding the GNU coreutils: Exploring the Design of Command-Line Utilities
item.content:encoded:
Decoding the GNU coreutils version 8.3 is a long-term project aimed at providing useful background for novice programmers exploring the design of command-line utilities. The project is divided into phases, with Phase 1 and Phase 2 already complete. Phase 1 focused on discussing the namespace and execution overview of each utility, while Phase 2 expanded on important design decisions and algorithms. The project also aims to provide a line-by-line code walkthrough for each utility in the future. The GNU coreutils, which are small, single-source file programs, have their own unique design patterns and often rely on the Getopt toolset for parsing command line options. The utilities also make use of the fts library for traversing the file system and include syscall wrappers and helpers from the Gnulib project. Overall, the project provides helpful insights into the design and implementation of the GNU coreutils.

147 Points | 36 comments

item.title: The rxv64 Operating System: MIT's xv6, in Rust, for SMP x86_64 machines (github.com)
item.description: rxv64: A Pedagogical Operating System Reimplementation of xv6 in Rust
item.content:encoded:
rxv64 is a pedagogical operating system written in Rust that targets multiprocessor x86_64 machines. It is a reimplementation of the xv6 operating system from MIT. The system supports limited hardware including the text-mode CGA device, serial port, PS/2 keyboard controller, and PCIe AHCI SATA storage devices. The xv6 README provides more information on its origin and intended use.

item.title: Scammers can exploit email forwarding flaws to impersonate high-profile domains (today.ucsd.edu)
item.description: Security Flaws in Email Forwarding Allow Scammers to Impersonate High-profile Domains
item.content:encoded:
Researchers at the University of California San Diego have discovered security flaws in the email forwarding process that allow scammers to impersonate high-profile domains. This vulnerability affects tens of thousands of domains, including government organizations, financial service companies, and major news organizations. The researchers found that scammers can send spoofed emails that bypass the safeguards of email providers like Gmail and Outlook, increasing the likelihood of recipients opening malicious attachments or clicking on harmful links. The vulnerabilities arise from the delegation of email infrastructure to third-party providers and the assumption that each organization operates its own mailing infrastructure. While some providers have patched the issues, the researchers recommend disabling open forwarding and implementing stricter validation policies to address the root problem.

87 Points | 31 comments

item.title: Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek documentary, 18 years later (mtlynch.io)
item.description: Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek Documentary, 18 Years Later - A Look into the Early Days of Tech Startup Founders
item.content:encoded:
Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek Documentary, 18 Years Later is a documentary film about Fog Creek's summer internship program in 2005. The film captures interviews with individuals who would go on to achieve fame and success in the tech industry. It explores the indie software scene of 2005, featuring Fog Creek Software, Y Combinator, and the launch of reddit. The documentary showcases the vulnerability and uncertainty experienced by tech startup founders during their early days. Despite its flaws, Aardvark'd provides a relatable and engaging look into the challenges of launching a software product. The film ends without a clear resolution, leaving viewers wondering about the outcome of the interns' project. The documentary includes insightful quotes from Paul Graham and Aaron Swartz. Surprisingly, Fog Creek did not finance the film, and the filmmaker recently uploaded it for free on YouTube.

370 Points | 128 comments

item.title: Just how constexpr is C++20â€™s std:string? (quuxplusone.github.io)
item.description: Understanding the constexprness of C++20's std::string
item.content:encoded:
C++20's std::string and std::vector can be marked as constexpr, allowing them to be used in compile-time programming. However, there are two constraints on constexprness: the value cannot depend on runtime input, and certain data cannot flow from compile-time into runtime. The article explains these constraints using examples of stack variables and memory addresses. It also discusses the limitations of constexpr string and vector, such as the inability to escape pointers to their data and the impact of small string optimization (SSO). The intended use of constexpr string and vector is as local variables or return types of constexpr or consteval functions, rather than as constexpr or constinit variables.

81 Points | 59 comments

item.description: Bun v1.0 Release: Bug Fixes, Improvements, and New Features
item.content:encoded:

The release also brings in uSockets and uWebSockets forks into Bun's repository. The changelog lists all the changes made from version 0.8.1 to 1.0.0. The release has seen contributions from new contributors as well. Overall, Bun v1.0 offers several enhancements and bug fixes for a better development experience.

730 Points | 245 comments

item.title: Losing Out in Critical Technologies: Cisco Systems and Financialization (www.ineteconomics.org)
item.description: Cisco Systems' Financialization and its Impact on US Technology Competitiveness
item.content:encoded:
Cisco Systems, once a global leader in telecommunication systems and the Internet, has fallen behind global competitors in critical technologies such as 5G and IoT. This is due to the company's shift from innovation to financialization, prioritizing stock buybacks over investments in cutting-edge communication-infrastructure products. Since 2001, Cisco has spent $152.3 billion on stock buybacks, wasting funds that could have been used for technological advancements. The company's focus on maximizing shareholder value has hindered its competitive position in the US information-and-communication-technology industry. This article explores Cisco's transformation from an innovative enterprise to a financialized one and discusses the implications for the industry's global competitiveness.

3 Points | 0 comments

item.title: Maybe Rust isnâ€™t a good tool for massively concurrent, userspace software (bitbashing.io)
item.description: Challenges and Limitations of Async Rust for Concurrency
item.content:encoded:
The article discusses the challenges and limitations of using async Rust for concurrency. It explains the difference between parallelism and concurrency and how breaking a problem into separate, independent parts can improve performance. The author explores the use of threads and mutex-based concurrency, highlighting the drawbacks and complexities involved. They then introduce the concept of channels as a synchronization mechanism and discuss how many modern languages, including Rust, provide channels in their standard libraries. The article also delves into the unique challenges of async Rust, such as the need to assure the compiler of data safety and the limitations of using Arc for dynamic lifetimes. Overall, the author suggests that while Rust may not be the best tool for massively concurrent, userspace software, it can still be valuable for other projects.

500 Points | 418 comments

item.title: Uber CEOâ€™s time moonlighting as a driver sparked all-hands called 'Why we suck.' (www.businessinsider.com)
item.description: Uber CEO's Time as a Driver Reveals Lack of Quality in Driver Product
item.content:encoded:
Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi reveals that his time as a driver for the company showed him a lack of quality in the driver product. He made an all-hands presentation titled 'Why we suck' based on his experiences. Khosrowshahi realized that the company was too focused on the rider and eater product and didn't pay enough attention to the driver product. He later shared what he learned with the company and set a new expectation. Despite his experiences, Khosrowshahi underestimated the cost of an Uber ride in New York City.

item.title: 'How Do You Know When Your Art Is Good?' (www.ask-polly.com)
item.description: Embracing Uncertainty and Enduring Pain: The Journey of an Artist
item.content:encoded:
Navigating the uncertainty of artistic success and the fear of judgment is a natural part of the creative process. The author shares their own experiences of self-doubt and the importance of tolerating discomfort in order to grow as an artist. They emphasize that feeling negative and upset about one's art is a sign of caring deeply about it, and that enduring the pain of creating art can ultimately make one stronger. The article concludes by highlighting the universal fear of being unloved and the transformative power of facing that fear through art.

4 Points | 0 comments

item.title: Artic Code Vault (archiveprogram.github.com)
item.description: GitHub Creates Arctic Code Vault to Preserve Open Source Software
item.content:encoded:
GitHub has created the Arctic Code Vault, a data repository stored in the Arctic World Archive (AWA) to preserve a snapshot of every active public repository as of 02/02/2020. The AWA is a long-term archival facility located in a decommissioned coal mine in the Svalbard archipelago. The archive is designed to last 1,000 years and is considered a stable site for preserving humanity's collective knowledge. The 02/02/2020 snapshot, consisting of 21TB of data, was stored on 186 reels of film and transported to the Arctic Code Vault. To recognize contributions, GitHub created the Arctic Code Vault Badge displayed on developers' profiles. The vault contains open source software from millions of developers worldwide.

14 Points | 10 comments

item.title: Cerabyte: ceramic storage poised to usher in 'yottabyte era' (www.tomshardware.com)
item.description: Cerabyte's Ceramic Storage Technology Aims to Revolutionize the Market
item.content:encoded:
Cerabyte, a German storage startup, claims that its ceramic nanolayer-based storage technology will disrupt the storage market by reducing data center storage TCO by 75%. The company plans to introduce CeraMemory cartridges (2025-30) with storage capacities between 10 PB and 100 PB, and CeraTape (2030-35) with up to 1 EB capacity per tape. Cerabyte's technology uses inorganic nanolayers to store information and can read and write data at GB/s class speeds. The company also highlights the durability and longevity of its ceramic storage, claiming that it can last over 5,000 years and withstand extreme temperatures and environments. Cerabyte's presentation at the 2023 Storage Developer Conference is highly anticipated.

52 Points | 21 comments

item.title: Debugging Catastrophic Backtracking for Regular Expressions in Python (krishnanchandra.com)
item.description: Fixing Catastrophic Backtracking in Regular Expressions in Python
item.content:encoded:
Fixing catastrophic backtracking in regular expressions in Python by using a non-greedy pattern. The article discusses how a regex pattern with a greedy subpattern can lead to exponential runtime on strings with many newlines, causing the application to become stuck. By making the repeating subpattern non-greedy and adding the re.DOTALL flag to match newlines, the runtime becomes linear instead of exponential. The article provides a comparison of the performance between the problematic regex and the fixed regex using a test script. The results show that the problematic regex performs poorly on long input sequences, while the fixed regex scales much better. The article concludes with a log-log plot illustrating the exponential relationship between input size and execution time for the problematic regex.

3 Points | 0 comments

item.title: ASMesh: Anonymous, Secure Messaging in Mesh Networks (eprint.iacr.org)
item.description: ASMesh: Anonymous and Secure Messaging in Mesh Networks Using Stronger, Anonymous Double Ratchet
item.content:encoded:
ASMesh is a new protocol that provides anonymous and secure messaging in mesh networks. It addresses the limitations of centralized service providers in scenarios like mass protests in censored networks. The protocol is designed to achieve forward and post-compromise security, as well as forward and post-compromise anonymity. It builds on Signal's Double Ratchet protocol and introduces enhancements to ensure strong confidentiality and anonymity under user corruptions. The protocol's security is proven and its performance is evaluated in simulated mesh networks. The paper also includes a proof of concept implementation.

5 Points | 0 comments

item.title: Atari pulls nostalgia power move and buys homebrew community forum (www.theregister.com)
item.description: Atari Acquires Retro Gaming Forum AtariAge to Enhance IP and Games
item.content:encoded:
Atari acquires retro gaming forum AtariAge to enhance its IP and games available for its hardware. The founder of AtariAge will become Atari's internal historian, and Atari has promised not to censor speech on the forums. The acquisition has been mostly met with approval by the community, as enthusiasm for an obsolete platform alone is not sustainable. However, some users have expressed concerns about monetization and Atari's reputation. The acquisition aligns with Atari's plans to revive the 2600 console and support vintage cartridges.

15 Points | 3 comments

item.title: The thinking path (www.robinsloan.com)
item.description: Robin Sloan's Excitement for His New Novel and Reflections on Creativity and Goodness
item.content:encoded:
Robin Sloan announces the upcoming publication of his new novel in June 2024 and shares his excitement. He discusses the influence of fantasy sagas on his previous novels and explores the idea of going beyond homage to actively participate in the genre. Sloan plans to create a rich introduction and companion for his new novel, incorporating various influences and media. He also reviews a novel by Michiko Aoyama and reflects on the need for creative investigations of decency and goodness. Sloan asks for nominations of great author websites and discusses the problem-solving power of walking. He concludes by highlighting the quality of science journalism and sharing an interesting logo treatment for Mattel Electronics.

132 Points | 30 comments

item.title: Digging through the New York Times morgue (buttondown.email)
item.description: Uncovering Treasures: Exploring the Transition to Computer Phototypesetting at The New York Times
item.content:encoded:
Researcher uncovers treasures from the transition to computer phototypesetting in the 1970s while digging through the New York Times morgue. The morgue contains millions of newspaper clippings, photographs, and other materials organized by subject matter. The researcher explores the transition from hot metal composition to computer phototypesetting at The Times in the 1970s, delving into the reasons behind the newspaper's delayed adoption of the technology. The visit to the morgue reveals internal publications documenting the transition and photos of the typesetting room. The researcher shares their process of organizing and analyzing the materials for their book on the topic.

25 Points | 7 comments
